articles.title: PGlite: PostgreSQL in WebAssembly (and TypeScript)
articles.description: People have brought Postgres into the browser before, albeit atop a Linux VM WASM layer. PGlite, however, packages a WASM build of Postgres into a TypeScript library that can be run in the browser or on Node.js or Bun and is only 3.7MB gzipped. You can play with a live deployment here.
articles.author: ElectricSQL / Neon

articles.title: JSR: What We Know So Far About Deno’s New JS Package Registry
articles.description: The Deno team is cooking up JSR (still behind a waitlist), a new JavaScript package registry (not merely a package management tool, like pnpm or Yarn) to address various npm limitations, including for Node users who don't even plan to use Deno.
articles.author: Sarah Gooding (Socket)

articles.title: Parcel v2.12.0: Now with Bun-Style Macros
articles.description: The popular zero-config build tool introduces support for bundle-time macros, such as those offered in Bun. The value returned by a macro is inlined into the bundle in place of the original call. There’s also a new online REPL where you can play with Parcel in the browser with support for most of Parcel’s features.
articles.author: Parcel.js

articles.title: Reporting Core Web Vitals with the Performance API
articles.description: The Performance API provides an interface to ways to measure and evaluate Web performance metrics from JavaScript. Geoff demonstrates how to use its capabilities to do your own performance reporting.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: A Fun Line of JavaScript Code
articles.description: Namely, using Promise.race to search through audio files forwards and backwards at the same time and stop as soon as the relevant metadata is found.
articles.author: David Bushell

articles.title: Next.js vs. Remix: A Developer's Dilemma
articles.description: Compares a variety of areas, from how various techniques are implemented through to deployment, support, and popularity.
articles.author: Chetan Gawai

articles.title: Why Does is-number Have 70+ Million Weekly Downloads?
articles.description: In part, it’s included in a chain of dependencies used by a very popular project.
articles.author: Shubham Jain

articles.title: 17 Equations That Changed the World - Rewritten in JavaScript
articles.description: This is quite neat if you enjoy a bit of math.
articles.author: RunJS

articles.title: PrimeVue 3.49.0: Vue UI Component Library
articles.description: A mature, rich set of open source UI components for Vue developers we first mentioned a few years ago. This new release includes components to enter one time passwords and a ‘stepper’ for wizard-style workflows. There’s also a new optional declarative syntax for using components that makes their code easier to read and write.
articles.author: PrimeTek

articles.title: Waku: A Minimal Server-Side React Framework
articles.description: From the maintainer of Jotai, Valtio, and Zustand, Waku is a lighter alternative to something like Next.js but that still opens up the potential of server components, shared components, and elegant routing, in a simpler, easier to apply way.
articles.author: Daishi Kato

articles.title: Embla Carousel 8: Carousel with Fluid Motion and 'Swipe Precision'
articles.description: Carousels are a popular, though often maligned, UI element, but the examples work pretty well for us. Library agnostic, but has easy integrations for React, Solid, and Angular, if you need them. The v8.0 release notes touch on many new features.
articles.author: David Jerleke

articles.title: Readability.js: Extract the Readable Content from an HTML Document
articles.description: A standalone version of the library used to power Firefox’s Reader View. It's been a few years since we've linked to this, but it continues to be improved.
articles.author: Mozilla

articles.title: Viz.js: Work with Graphviz in the Browser
articles.description: Graphviz is a suite of open source graph drawing tools of some 30+ years’ vintage. Viz.js is a WebAssembly Graphviz build that brings some of its functionality into the browser, as seen in the homepage's live demo (above). GitHub repo.
articles.author: Michael Daines

articles.title: 🎨 Vue Color Wheel: A Wheel-Style Color Picker for Vue 3
articles.description: Far from a new idea, but elegantly demonstrated on its homepage. Coloris is a nice, vanilla alternative in this space, if the wheel view isn't a necessity.
articles.author: Robert Shaw

articles.title: WXT: Next-Gen Web Extension Framework
articles.description: A framework for creating cross-browser extensions. You can target Chrome, Firefox, Edge and Safari. Plasmo is another option in this space.
articles.author: WXT

articles.description: TypeScript 5.4 RC has been released, packing lots of small changes, as well as Object.groupBy, Map.groupBy, and type narrowing enhancements.
Christopher Chedeau (aka Vjeux) has written about his 12 years at Meta, including being involved in the early days of both React and React Native.
A summary of recent updates to the V8 JavaScript engine.
🇪🇺 Fed up with Apple's nonsense around removing PWA support in the European Union? Open Web Advocacy has an open letter you can co-sign.
Express.js 4.18.3 – The first release in sixteen months. 😁
Deno 1.41 – Now with much smaller deno compile binary sizes, official Linux ARM64 binaries, and improvements to Node.js compatibility.
Playwright 1.42 – Browser remote control and runner toolkit.
Babel 7.24.0 – Supports importing JSON modules and updates its Decorators implementation.
TinyMCE 7.0 – Rich text editor component – now GPL licensed.

articles.title: An Interactive Guide to CSS :has()
articles.description: A superb, extensive guide to everything that you practically need to know about the versatile :has() selector. It's packed with loads of code examples and interactive elements, and will no doubt help unlock some thoughts on how you can use this powerful selector in your own projects.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: Lift-Off: The MDN Curriculum Launch
articles.description: The MDN Curriculum is a new resource on the excellent MDN, providing a structured guide to essential frontend skills and best practices for industry newcomers. You can find it here.
articles.author: Hermina Condei (MozDevNet)

articles.title: Open Letter to Tim Cook: Sabotaging Web Apps is Indefensible
articles.description: This seeks to halt upcoming changes to PWAs in iOS and Safari for users in the European Union. You can sign it too.
articles.author: Open Web Advocacy

articles.title: Home Screen Advantage
articles.description: Alex shares that Apple’s efforts to “maintain its home screen advantage” with these upcoming PWA changes is “a shocking attempt to keep the web from ever emerging as a true threat to the App Store”.
articles.author: Alex Russell opinion

articles.title: View Transitions: Handling Aspect Ratio Changes
articles.description: If your view transition animations don’t look quite right, Jake notes how it’s typically due to the content changing aspect ratio, and then shares how to fix it.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: Mobile Accessibility Barriers for Assistive Technology Users
articles.description: A collection of lessons learned from assistive technology users, highlighting the challenges and barriers they encounter on mobile devices.
articles.author: Kate Kalcevich

articles.title: Going Beyond Pixels and (r)ems in CSS: Container Query Length Units
articles.description: A look at container query length units, and how these units are increasingly essential in modern CSS development.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: Designing with Integrity: The Ethical Designer's Handbook on Dark Patterns
articles.description: A detailed look at the deceptive design tactics of dark patterns, how they attempt to manipulate users into unintended actions, and generally pose an ethical dilemma in the design realm.
articles.author: Jan Nikka A. Estefani

articles.title: The Linear Look
articles.description: An overview of a particularly dominant web design trend in the SaaS/tech space.
articles.author: Alex Trost

articles.title: Functional UI Kit: A Unified Figma and React UI Component Kit
articles.description: It hasn’t felt like anyone perfected the Figma - React connection yet, but this is a great attempt to bridge the design/code gap, funded by Figma’s Community Creators Fund.
articles.author: Alex Yakir et al.

articles.title: Mojo CSS: An Atomic CSS Framework with Near-Zero Runtime
articles.description: Another player in the atomic CSS game, with some features you might not find in more popular solutions, including color tinting, component abstraction, reverse breakpoints, among others.
articles.author: Mojo CSS

articles.title: WebPerf Snippets
articles.description: A curated list of snippets to get Web Performance metrics to use in the browser console or as snippets on Chrome DevTools.
articles.author: Joan León

articles.title: Shoelace: 'A Forward-Thinking Library of Web Components'
articles.description: We’ve featured this collection of well designed UI components before, but you may want to take another look now that web components are the talk of the town.
articles.author: Cory LaViska

articles.title: Pico.css: A Minimal CSS Framework for Semantic HTML
articles.description: The focus is more on styling native HTML elements, rather than littering your HTML with classes. Includes dark and light mode themes out-of-the-box.
articles.author: Lucas Larroche

articles.title: Color Legend Element: A Web Component Providing a Legend in Data Visualizations
articles.description: Built with Lit/Lit-Element and D3.js. You can see various examples here. It’s legen.. wait for it.. dary.
articles.author: Chris Henrick
